### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 53 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Leatherbacks, the largest of the sea turtles, when subjected to the conditions of captivity, are susceptible to a wide variety of fatal diseases with which they would never come in contact if they lived in the wild. It is surprising, therefore, that the likelihood that a leatherback will reach its theoretical maximum life expectancy is about the same whether that animal is living in captivity or in the wild.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to resolve the apparent discrepancy?
Choices:
  A: Fewer diseases attach leatherbacks than attack other large aquatic reptiles.
  B: The average life expectancy of sea turtles in general is longer than that of almost all other marine animals.
  C: Most leatherbacks that perish in the wild are killed by predators.
  D: Few zoologists have sufficient knowledge to establish an artificial environment that is conducive to the well-being of captive leatherbacks.
  E: The size of a leatherback is an untrustworthy indicator of its age.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  Leatherbacks are susceptible to fatal diseases in captivity.
  Leatherbacks have the same likelihood of reaching their maximum life expectancy whether in captivity or in the wild.
  
A: This statement is irrelevant to the discrepancy between the life expectancy of leatherbacks in captivity and in the wild.
B: This statement is also irrelevant to the discrepancy between the life expectancy of leatherbacks in captivity and in the wild.
C: This statement provides a possible explanation for why the life expectancy of leatherbacks in captivity is similar to that of leatherbacks in the wild. If most leatherbacks that perish in the wild are killed by predators, then the ones that survive are less likely to die from diseases, which could explain why their life expectancy is similar to that of leatherbacks in captivity.
D: This statement is irrelevant to the discrepancy between the life expectancy of leatherbacks in captivity and in the wild.
E: This statement is also irrelevant to the discrepancy between the life expectancy of leatherbacks in captivity and in the wild.

Action: Answer("C")
Response 1:
Knowledge:
  Leatherbacks are susceptible to fatal diseases in captivity.
  Leatherbacks have the same likelihood of reaching their maximum life expectancy in captivity or in the wild.
  
A: This statement provides information about other aquatic reptiles, but it does not help to resolve the discrepancy between the life expectancy of leatherbacks in captivity and in the wild.
B: This statement provides information about the life expectancy of sea turtles in general, but it does not help to resolve the discrepancy between the life expectancy of leatherbacks in captivity and in the wild.
C: This statement provides information about the cause of death of leatherbacks in the wild, but it does not help to resolve the discrepancy between the life expectancy of leatherbacks in captivity and in the wild.
D: This statement provides information about the difficulty of establishing an artificial environment that is conducive to the well-being of captive leatherbacks, but it does not help to resolve the discrepancy between the life expectancy of leatherbacks in captivity and in the wild.
E: If the size of a leatherback is an untrustworthy indicator of its age, then it is possible that captive leatherbacks are not actually living as long as they appear to be. This could help to explain why leatherbacks in captivity have the same likelihood of reaching their maximum life expectancy as those in the wild.

Context: It is likely that most of the new television programs Wilke & Wilke produce for this season will be canceled. Most of the new shows they produced last season were canceled due to insufficient viewership. Furthermore, their new shows are all police dramas, and few police dramas have been popular in recent years.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to strengthen the argument?
Choices:
  A: Wilke & Wilke have produced more new shows for this season than they produced last season.
  B: Most of the shows that Wilke & Wilke produced last year were police dramas.
  C: None of the shows that Wilke & Wilke produced last year that were not canceled were police dramas.
  D: All of the new shows that Wilke & Wilke produced last year that were canceled were police dramas.
  E: None of the most popular television shows last year were police dramas.

  D: This statement supports the argument that police dramas are not popular, as all of the new shows that were canceled were police dramas.

Topic: Law
Context: History provides many examples of technological innovations being strongly resisted by people whose working conditions without those innovations were miserable. This shows that social inertia is a more powerful determinant of human behavior than is the desire for comfort or safety.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously undermines the reasoning in the argument?
Choices:
  A: People correctly believe that technological innovations often cause job loss.
  B: People are often reluctant to take on new challenges.
  C: Some examples of technological innovation have been embraced by workers.
  D: People tend to adapt easily to gradually implemented technological innovations.
  E: People correctly believe that technological innovations almost always increase workers' productivity.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The argument claims that social inertia is a more powerful determinant of human behavior than is the desire for comfort or safety, and that technological innovations are strongly resisted by people whose working conditions without those innovations were miserable.

  B: This statement is not directly related to the argument and does not undermine it.
  C: This statement weakens the argument by providing an example of workers embracing technological innovation.
  D: This statement weakens the argument by suggesting that people can adapt to technological innovations.
  E: This statement is not directly related to the argument and does not undermine it.

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 56 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: We can be sure that at least some halogen lamps are well crafted, because halogen lamps from most major manufacturers are on display at Furniture Labyrinth. Any item on display at Furniture Labyrinth is well crafted.
Question: Which one of the following arguments is most similar in its reasoning to the argument above?
Choices:
  A: We can be confident that the temperature will drop abruptly on at least one day this week, for there is a chance of storms most days this week; whenever there are storms, the temperature drops suddenly.
  B: We can be positive that there are at least a few disturbing sonnets, given that Melinda has written several different kinds of sonnets; everything Melinda writes is disturbing.
  C: We can be sure that Gianna will get at least some good mechanical work done to her car, because she can have her car worked on at any of several shops in the city, and every shop is capable of doing good mechanical work.
  D: We can be positive that at least some minnows are healthy, because many different species of minnow can be found in lakes nearby, and every lake nearby is teeming with healthy fish.
  E: We can be confident that the cornmeal used at Matteo's Trattoria is healthful and organic, since cornmeal is among the ingredients used in preparing meals there; whenever a meal is prepared at Matteo's Trattoria, only healthful, organic ingredients are used.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The argument states that halogen lamps from most major manufacturers are on display at Furniture Labyrinth and any item on display at Furniture Labyrinth is well crafted.
  A: The argument states that there is a chance of storms most days this week and whenever there are storms, the temperature drops suddenly.
  B: The argument states that everything Melinda writes is disturbing and Melinda has written several different kinds of sonnets.
  C: The argument states that Gianna can have her car worked on at any of several shops in the city, and every shop is capable of doing good mechanical work.
  D: The argument states that many different species of minnow can be found in lakes nearby, and every lake nearby is teeming with healthy fish.
  E: The argument states that cornmeal is among the ingredients used in preparing meals at Matteo's Trattoria and whenever a meal is prepared at Matteo's Trattoria, only healthful, organic ingredients are used.
Action: Answer("C")

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 57 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Harrold Foods is attempting to dominate the soft-drink market by promoting "Hero," its most popular carbonated drink product, with a costly new advertising campaign. But survey results show that, in the opinion of 72 percent of all consumers, "Hero" already dominates the market. Since any product with more than 50 percent of the sales in a market is, by definition, dominant in that market, Harrold Foods dominates the market now and need only maintain its current market share in order to continue to do so.
Question: The argument commits which one of the following errors in reasoning?
Choices:
  A: failing to exclude the possibility that what appears to be the result of a given market condition may in fact be the cause of that condition
  B: mistaking a condition required if a certain result is to obtain for a condition that by itself is sufficient to guarantee that result
  C: treating the failure to establish that a certain claim is false as equivalent to a demonstration that that claim is true
  D: taking evidence that a claim is believed to be true to constitute evidence that the claim is in fact true
  E: describing survey results that were obtained in the past as if they are bound to obtain in the future as well
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The argument is that Harrold Foods dominates the soft-drink market because "Hero" already dominates the market in the opinion of 72% of all consumers. The argument assumes that the current market share of "Hero" will remain the same in the future.
  A: This answer choice is not relevant to the argument.
  B: This answer choice is not relevant to the argument.
  C: This answer choice is not relevant to the argument.
  D: This answer choice is not relevant to the argument.
  E: This answer choice correctly identifies the error in the argument. The argument assumes that the survey results obtained in the past will hold true in the future, which is not necessarily the case.
Action: Answer("E")

  The survey results show that 72 percent of all consumers believe that "Hero" already dominates the market.
  The conclusion is that Harrold Foods dominates the market now and need only maintain its current market share in order to continue to do so.
  
Analysis:
  The argument seems to be based on a misunderstanding of the definition of market dominance. The fact that 72 percent of consumers believe that "Hero" dominates the market does not necessarily mean that it actually does. The argument assumes that the survey results are an accurate reflection of the market, but it provides no evidence to support this assumption. Therefore, the argument commits the error of mistaking a condition required if a certain result is to obtain for a condition that by itself is sufficient to guarantee that result.

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 58 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Science journalist: Brown dwarfs are celestial objects with more mass than planets but less mass than stars. They are identified by their mass and whether or not lithium is present in their atmospheres. Stars at least as massive as the Sun have lithium remaining in their atmospheres because the mixing of elements in their internal nuclear furnaces is incomplete. Stars with less mass than the Sun have no lithium because the element has been fully mixed into their nuclear furnaces and consumed. A brown dwarf does not have a fully functional nuclear furnace and so its lithium cannot be consumed.
Question: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the science journalist's statements?
Choices:
  A: Any celestial object without lithium in its atmosphere is a star with less mass than the Sun.
  B: Any celestial object with lithium in its atmosphere has a nuclear furnace that has incompletely mixed the object's elements.
  C: No celestial object that has no lithium in its atmosphere is a brown dwarf.
  D: No celestial object with lithium in its atmosphere has less mass than the Sun.
  E: No celestial object less massive than a brown dwarf has lithium in its atmosphere.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  Brown dwarfs are celestial objects with more mass than planets but less mass than stars.
  Brown dwarfs are identified by their mass and whether or not lithium is present in their atmospheres.
  Stars at least as massive as the Sun have lithium remaining in their atmospheres because the mixing of elements in their internal nuclear furnaces is incomplete.
  Stars with less mass than the Sun have no lithium because the element has been fully mixed into their nuclear furnaces and consumed.
  A brown dwarf does not have a fully functional nuclear furnace and so its lithium cannot be consumed.

Action: Answer("B")  
The science journalist's statements suggest that any celestial object with lithium in its atmosphere has a nuclear furnace that has incompletely mixed the object's elements.

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 59 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A computer game publisher has recently released its latest adventure game. The game's inventive puzzles and compelling plot induce even casual players to become preoccupied with completing it. The game can be purchased from retail outlets or rented for two-day intervals. The publisher offers a rebate equal to the cost of one rental for renters who go on to purchase the game, saving them a significant portion of the purchase price. Since the rate of sales now meets expectations and rentals are exceeding expectations, the publisher predicts that soon sales of the game will also exceed expectations.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to justify the publisher's prediction?
Choices:
  A: The game can be purchased directly from the publisher as well as from retailers.
  B: It takes several weeks for most players to complete the game.
  C: The publisher's games are among the most popular computer games on the market.
  D: Most people who complete the game do not play it extensively afterward.
  E: Some people buy and complete the game and then give it away to a friend.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The game publisher has released a new adventure game that can be purchased or rented.
  The publisher offers a rebate equal to the cost of one rental for renters who go on to purchase the game.
  The rate of sales meets expectations and rentals are exceeding expectations.
  The publisher predicts that soon sales of the game will also exceed expectations.
A: This statement does not provide any information that helps to justify the publisher's prediction.
B: If it takes several weeks for most players to complete the game, it is likely that they will rent the game multiple times before completing it. This would increase the number of rentals and could lead to more purchases, which would justify the publisher's prediction.
C: This statement provides information about the popularity of the publisher's games, but it does not provide any information that helps to justify the publisher's prediction.
D: If most people who complete the game do not play it extensively afterward, it is less likely that they will recommend the game to others, which could lead to fewer purchases. This would weaken the publisher's prediction.
E: If some people buy and complete the game and then give it away to a friend, it is less likely that those friends will purchase the game themselves. This would weaken the publisher's prediction.
Action: Answer("B")

  The publisher offers a rebate equal to the cost of one rental for renters who go on to purchase the game.
  The rate of sales meets expectations and rentals are exceeding expectations.
  
A: This statement does not provide any information that helps to justify the publisher's prediction.
B: If it takes several weeks for most players to complete the game, then they may need to rent the game multiple times before they complete it. This could lead to an increase in rentals and purchases, justifying the publisher's prediction.
C: This statement provides information about the popularity of the publisher's games, but it does not provide any information that helps to justify the publisher's prediction.
D: If most people who complete the game do not play it extensively afterward, then they may be more likely to purchase the game instead of renting it again. This could lead to an increase in purchases, justifying the publisher's prediction.
E: This statement does not provide any information that helps to justify the publisher's prediction.

Context: Had the party's economic theories been sound and had it succeeded in implementing its program, the inflation rate would have lessened considerably. But because the inflation rate actually increased, the party's economic theories were fur off the mark.
Question: The flawed reasoning in which one oflbe following arguments most closely resembles the flawed reasoning in the argument above?
Choices:
  A: If the people who inhabited the valley for so long had been invaded, or iflbere had been a dramatic climatic change, there would have been chaoges in the valley's architecture. But architecture in the valley remained the same throughout their stay. Thus, the valley people must not have been invaded at any time during their stay.
  B: Many people fear that iflbe opposition party wins the election and keeps its promise to cut wages dramatically, workers in key industries will strike. But because the workers have promised not to strike, these workers must think the party will not keep its promise of a dramatic wage cut.
  C: If the company had succeeded in selling its subsidiaries and used the cash to purchase the new patent, its stock price would have doubled in the last two years. But the price oflbe stock did not increase in that time. Thus, the company must have failed to sell its subsidiaries.
  D: City residents were expected to show a great deal of support for the rebels iflbe battle was won and the jailed rebel leaders freed. Residents have shown a great deal of support or the rebels for the last three days. Therefore, the rebels must have won the battle.

Topic: Law
Context: Government official: Residents who are foreign citizens can serve as public servants at most levels, but not as cabinet secretaries. This is wise, since cabinet secretaries perform some duties that should be performed only by citizens, and no one should be appointed to a position if it involves duties that person should not perform. Moreover, a cabinet undersecretary is expected to serve as cabinet secretary when the actual secretary is unavailable. So, ____.
Question: Which one of the following most logically completes the government official's statement?
Choices:
  A: foreign citizens who serve as public servants should be granted citizenship in the country they serve
  B: foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet undersecretaries
  C: only former cabinet undersecretaries should be appointed as cabinet secretaries
  D: foreign citizens should be eligible to serve as cabinet secretaries
  E: cabinet undersecretaries should not be expected to stand in for cabinet secretaries
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The government official argues that foreign citizens can serve as public servants at most levels, but not as cabinet secretaries. ### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 62 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Figorian Wildlife Commission: The development of wetlands in industrialized nations for residential and commercial uses has endangered many species. To protect wildlife we must regulate such development in Figoria: future wetland development must be offset by the construction of replacement wetland habitats. Thus, development would cause no net reduction of wetlands and pose no threat to the species that inhabit them. Figorian Development Commission: Other nations have flagrantly developed wetlands at the expense of wildlife. We have conserved. Since Figorian wetland development might not affect wildlife and is necessary for growth, we should allow development. We have as much right to govern our own resources as countries that have already put their natural resources to commercial use.
Question: Which one of the following principles, if accepted, would most strongly support the Figorian Development Commission's position against the Figorian Wildlife Commission's position?
Choices:
  A: National resources should be regulated by international agreement when wildlife is endangered.
  B: The right of future generations to have wildlife preserved supersedes the economic needs of individual nations.
  C: Only when a reduction of populations of endangered species by commercial development has been found should regulation be implemented to prevent further damage.
  D: Environment regulation must aim at preventing any further environmental damage and cannot allow for the different degrees to which different nations have already harmed the environment.
  E: It is imprudent to allow further depletion of natural resources.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The Figorian Wildlife Commission argues that wetland development should be regulated to protect wildlife, and that future wetland development must be offset by the construction of replacement wetland habitats. 
  The Figorian Development Commission argues that Figoria should be allowed to develop wetlands, as it might not affect wildlife and is necessary for growth, and that Figoria has the right to govern its own resources.
  A: This principle suggests that international agreement should regulate national resources when wildlife is endangered, which does not support the Figorian Development Commission's position.
  B: This principle suggests that the right of future generations to have wildlife preserved supersedes the economic needs of individual nations, which does not support the Figorian Development Commission's position.
  C: This principle suggests that regulation should only be implemented when a reduction of populations of endangered species by commercial development has been found, which does support the Figorian Development Commission's position.
  D: This principle suggests that environmental regulation must aim at preventing any further environmental damage and cannot allow for the different degrees to which different nations have already harmed the environment, which does not support the Figorian Development Commission's position.
  E: This principle suggests that it is imprudent to allow further depletion of natural resources, which does not support the Figorian Development Commission's position.
Action: Answer("C")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  The Figorian Wildlife Commission argues that wetland development should be regulated to protect wildlife by offsetting it with the construction of replacement wetland habitats.
  The Figorian Development Commission argues that wetland development is necessary for growth and that they have the right to govern their own resources.
  A: This principle suggests that international agreement should regulate national resources when wildlife is endangered, which does not support either position.
  B: This principle suggests that the right of future generations to have wildlife preserved supersedes the economic needs of individual nations, which supports the Figorian Wildlife Commission's position.
  C: This principle suggests that regulation should only be implemented when a reduction of populations of endangered species by commercial development has been found, which does not support either position.
  D: This principle suggests that environmental regulation must aim at preventing any further environmental damage and cannot allow for the different degrees to which different nations have already harmed the environment, which does not support the Figorian Development Commission's position.
  E: This principle suggests that it is imprudent to allow further depletion of natural resources, which does not support the Figorian Development Commission's position.
Action: Answer("B")
Response 2:
Knowledge: 
  The Figorian Wildlife Commission argues that future wetland development must be offset by the construction of replacement wetland habitats to protect wildlife.
  The Figorian Development Commission argues that Figorian wetland development might not affect wildlife and is necessary for growth, and that they have as much right to govern their own resources as countries that have already put their natural resources to commercial use.
  A: This principle suggests that national resources should be regulated by international agreement when wildlife is endangered, which would support the Figorian Wildlife Commission's position.
  B: This principle suggests that the right of future generations to have wildlife preserved supersedes the economic needs of individual nations, which would support the Figorian Wildlife Commission's position.
  C: This principle suggests that regulation should only be implemented when a reduction of populations of endangered species by commercial development has been found, which does not support either position.
  D: This principle suggests that environment regulation must aim at preventing any further environmental damage and cannot allow for the different degrees to which different nations have already harmed the environment, which would support the Figorian Wildlife Commission's position.
  E: This principle suggests that it is imprudent to allow further depletion of natural resources, which would support the Figorian Wildlife Commission's position.
Action: Answer("D")

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 63 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Columnist: Although most people favor the bill and the bill does not violate anyone's basic human rights, it will not be passed for many years, if at all; nor will any similar bill. Those people who would be adversely affected were it to become law are very influential. This shows that, if this country is a democracy at all, it is not a well-functioning one.
Question: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most helps to justify the columnist's reasoning?
Choices:
  A: In a well-functioning democracy, any bill that would benefit most people will be passed into law within a few years if it does not violate anyone's basic human rights.
  B: If a democracy is well functioning, then any bill that is opposed by influential people but favored by most other people will eventually pass into law.
  C: In a well-functioning democracy, a bill that is favored by most people will become law within a few years only if those who oppose it are not very influential.
  D: Any bill passed into law in a well-functioning democracy will be favored by most people and be consistent with individuals' basic human rights.
  E: A bill that most people favor will be passed promptly into law in a well-functioning democracy if the bill does not violate anyone's basic human rights.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The columnist argues that a bill that is favored by most people and does not violate anyone's basic human rights will not be passed into law if those who oppose it are very influential.
  A: This principle suggests that any bill that would benefit most people will be passed into law within a few years if it does not violate anyone's basic human rights, which is not relevant to the columnist's argument.
  B: This principle suggests that any bill that is opposed by influential people but favored by most other people will eventually pass into law, which contradicts the columnist's argument.

  E: This principle suggests that a bill that most people favor will be passed promptly into law in a well-functioning democracy if the bill does not violate anyone's basic human rights, which is not relevant to the columnist's argument.

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 64 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Editorial: The premier's economic advisor assures her that with the elimination of wasteful spending the goal of reducing taxes while not significantly decreasing government services can be met. But the premier should not listen to this advisor, who in his youth was convicted of embezzlement. Surely his economic advice is as untrustworthy as he is himself, and so the premier should discard any hope of reducing taxes without a significant decrease in government services.
Question: Which one of the following is a questionable argumentative strategy employed in the editorial's argument?
Choices:
  A: rejecting a proposal on the grounds that a particular implementation of the proposal is likely to fail
  B: trying to win support for a proposal by playing on people's fears of what could happen otherwise
  C: criticizing the source of a claim rather than examining the claim itself
  D: taking lack of evidence for a claim as evidence undermining that claim
  E: presupposing what it sets out to establish
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The editorial argues that the premier should not listen to her economic advisor because he was convicted of embezzlement in his youth. The editorial assumes that the advisor's economic advice is untrustworthy because of his past conviction.
A: This choice describes a valid argumentative strategy.
B: This choice describes a questionable argumentative strategy, but it is not employed in the editorial's argument.
C: This choice describes a questionable argumentative strategy, and it is employed in the editorial's argument.
D: This choice describes a questionable argumentative strategy, but it is not employed in the editorial's argument.
E: This choice describes a questionable argumentative strategy, but it is not employed in the editorial's argument.

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 65 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Biologist: Humans have five fingers because we descended from a fish with five phalanges in its fins. Despite our prejudices to the contrary, our configuration of fingers is no more or less useful than several other possible configurations, e.g., six per hand. So, if humans had descended from a fish with six phalanges in its fins and had six fingers on each hand, then we would be just as content with that configuration.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the biologist's argument?
Choices:
  A: Everyone is equally content with our present configuration of fingers.
  B: Humans are never equally content with two things of unequal usefulness.
  C: Humans are always equally content with two things of equal usefulness.
  D: The perceived usefulness of our configuration of fingers is an illusory result of our prejudices.
  E: At least one species of fish had six phalanges in its fins.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The biologist argues that humans could have been content with a different configuration of fingers if we had descended from a fish with a different number of phalanges in its fins.
  A: This statement does not provide any evidence to support the biologist's argument.
  B: This statement contradicts the biologist's argument by suggesting that humans are not content with things of unequal usefulness.
  C: This statement contradicts the biologist's argument by suggesting that humans are always content with things of equal usefulness.
  D: This statement supports the biologist's argument by suggesting that the perceived usefulness of our configuration of fingers is not based on objective criteria.
  E: This statement weakens the biologist's argument by suggesting that humans could have descended from a fish with six phalanges in its fins and still have five fingers.
Action: Answer("D")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  The biologist argues that humans could have been content with six fingers per hand if we had descended from a fish with six phalanges in its fins.
  A: This statement does not provide any evidence to support the biologist's argument.
  B: This statement contradicts the biologist's argument by suggesting that humans are not content with things of unequal usefulness.

Context: Dried parsley should never be used in cooking, for it is far less tasty and healthful than fresh parsley is.
Question: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most clearly helps to justify the argument above?
Choices:
  A: Fresh ingredients should be used in cooking whenever possible.
  B: Only the tastiest ingredients should ever be used in cooking.
  C: Ingredients that should never be used in cooking are generally neither tasty nor healthful.
  D: Parsley that is not both tasty and healthful should never be used in cooking.
  E: In cooking, dried ingredients are inferior to fresh ingredients.

Topic: Law
Context: Detective: Because the embezzler must have had specialized knowledge and access to internal financial records, we can presume that the embezzler worked for XYZ Corporation as either an accountant or an actuary. But an accountant would probably not make the kind of mistakes in ledger entries that led to the discovery of the embezzlement. Thus it is likely that the embezzler is one of the actuaries.
Question: Each of the following weakens the detective's argument EXCEPT:
Choices:
  A: The actuaries' activities while working for XYZ Corporation were more closely scrutinized by supervisors than were the activities of the accountants.
  B: There is evidence of breaches in computer security at the time of the embezzlement that could have given persons outside XYZ Corporation access to internal financial records.
  C: XYZ Corporation employs eight accountants, whereas it has only two actuaries on its staff.
  D: An independent report released before the crime took place concluded that XYZ Corporation was vulnerable to embezzlement.
  E: Certain security measures at XYZ Corporation made it more difficult for the actuaries to have access to internal financial records than for the accountants.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The detective's argument is that the embezzler is likely one of the actuaries because an accountant would not make the kind of mistakes that led to the discovery of the embezzlement.
  A: If the actuaries' activities were more closely scrutinized than the accountants', it would make it less likely that one of the actuaries was the embezzler, weakening the detective's argument. 
  B: If persons outside XYZ Corporation had access to internal financial records, it would mean that the embezzler could have been someone other than an accountant or actuary, weakening the detective's argument.
  C: The number of accountants and actuaries employed by XYZ Corporation is not relevant to the detective's argument.
  D: The independent report released before the crime took place is not relevant to the detective's argument.
  E: If certain security measures made it more difficult for the actuaries to have access to internal financial records than for the accountants, it would make it less likely that one of the actuaries was the embezzler, weakening the detective's argument.

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 68 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: One should not play a practical joke on someone if it shows contempt for that person or if one believes it might bring significant harm to that person.
Question: The principle stated above, if valid, most helps to justify the reasoning in which one of the following arguments?
Choices:
  A: I should not have played that practical joke on you yesterday. Even if it was not contemptuous, I should have realized that it would bring significant harm to someone.
  B: I have no reason to think that the practical joke I want to play would harm anyone. So, since the joke would show no contempt for the person the joke is played on, it would not be wrong for me to play it.
  C: Because of the circumstances, it would be wrong for me to play the practical joke I had intended to play on you. Even though it would not show contempt for anyone, it could easily bring you significant harm.
  D: It would have been wrong for me to play the practical joke that I had intended to play on you. Even though I did not have reason to think that it would significantly harm anyone, I did think that it would show contempt for someone.
  E: Someone was harmed as a result of my practical joke. Thus, even though it did not show contempt for the person I played the joke on, I should not have played it.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The principle stated above says that one should not play a practical joke on someone if it shows contempt for that person or if one believes it might bring significant harm to that person.
  A: This argument acknowledges that the practical joke would bring significant harm to someone, which is in line with the principle stated above.
  B: This argument assumes that the practical joke would not bring significant harm to anyone, but the principle stated above says that one should not play a practical joke if one believes it might bring significant harm to someone.
  C: This argument acknowledges that the practical joke could bring significant harm to someone, which is in line with the principle stated above.
  D: This argument acknowledges that the practical joke would show contempt for someone, which is in line with the principle stated above.
  E: This argument acknowledges that someone was harmed as a result of the practical joke, which is in line with the principle stated above.

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 69 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A film makes a profit if the number of people who see it is sufficient to generate revenues from ticket sales greater than the amount spent to make it. Hence, the primary goal of movie executives is to maximize the number of people who see a film. However, it is not the primary goal of television executives to maximize the number of viewers for their shows.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to explain the difference between the goals of movie executives and those of television executives?
Choices:
  A: More people are willing to see a film more than once than are willing to watch a television show more than once.
  B: There is no analog in television to the large profits that owners of movie theaters make by selling refreshments to their customers.
  C: The average cost of producing an hour of film is much greater than the average cost of producing an hour of television.
  D: Television shows make their profits from sponsors, who are chiefly concerned with the purchasing power of the people who watch a television show.
  E: Over half of the most popular television shows are shows that viewers do not have to pay to watch.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The primary goal of movie executives is to maximize the number of people who see a film, while it is not the primary goal of television executives to maximize the number of viewers for their shows.
  A: More people seeing a film more than once than watching a television show more than once does not explain the difference in goals between movie and television executives.
  B: The absence of an analog in television to the large profits that owners of movie theaters make by selling refreshments to their customers does not explain the difference in goals between movie and television executives.
  C: The average cost of producing an hour of film being much greater than the average cost of producing an hour of television does not explain the difference in goals between movie and television executives.
  D: If television shows make their profits from sponsors, who are chiefly concerned with the purchasing power of the people who watch a television show, this would explain why television executives are not primarily concerned with maximizing the number of viewers for their shows.
  E: Over half of the most popular television shows being shows that viewers do not have to pay to watch does not explain the difference in goals between movie and television executives.
Action: Answer("D")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  The primary goal of movie executives is to maximize the number of people who see a film in order to make a profit.
  The primary goal of television executives is not to maximize the number of viewers for their shows.
Choices:
  A: This statement provides information about the willingness of people to see a film or watch a television show more than once, but it does not explain the difference between the goals of movie executives and those of television executives.
  B: This statement provides information about the profits of movie theaters, but it does not explain the difference between the goals of movie executives and those of television executives.
  C: This statement provides information about the cost of producing an hour of film compared to the cost of producing an hour of television, which could explain the difference between the goals of movie executives and those of television executives. If it is more expensive to produce a film, then movie executives would need to maximize the number of people who see the film in order to make a profit, while television executives may not need to maximize the number of viewers as much if it is less expensive to produce a television show.
  D: This statement provides information about the profits of television shows, but it does not explain the difference between the goals of movie executives and those of television executives.
  E: This statement provides information about the popularity of television shows that viewers do not have to pay to watch, but it does not explain the difference between the goals of movie executives and those of television executives.

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 70 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Curator: Our museum displays only twentieth-century works, which are either on loan from private collectors or in the museum's permanent collection. Prints of all of the latter works are available in the museum store. The museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection, such as Hopper's Nighthawks.
Question: If the curator's statements are true, which one of the following must be true?
Choices:
  A: Every print in the museum store is of a work that is either on loan to the museum from a private collector or part of the museum's permanent collection.
  B: Every print that is sold in the museum store is a copy of a twentieth-century work.
  C: There are prints in the museum store of every work that is displayed in the museum and not on loan from a private collector.
  D: Hopper's Nighthawks is both a twentieth-century work and a work on loan to the museum from a private collector.
  E: Hopper's Nighthawks is not displayed in the museum.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  - The museum displays only twentieth-century works.
  - The works displayed are either on loan from private collectors or in the museum's permanent collection.
  - Prints of all of the latter works are available in the museum store.
  - The museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection, such as Hopper's Nighthawks.
  
A: It is not necessarily true that every print in the museum store is of a work that is either on loan to the museum from a private collector or part of the museum's permanent collection. The museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection.
B: It is not necessarily true that every print that is sold in the museum store is a copy of a twentieth-century work. The museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection.
C: It is not necessarily true that there are prints in the museum store of every work that is displayed in the museum and not on loan from a private collector. The museum store only sells prints of works that are in the museum's permanent collection.
D: It is not necessarily true that Hopper's Nighthawks is both a twentieth-century work and a work on loan to the museum from a private collector. The statement only says that Hopper's Nighthawks is not part of the museum's permanent collection.
E: It is not necessarily true that Hopper's Nighthawks is not displayed in the museum. The statement does not provide any information about whether Hopper's Nighthawks is displayed in the museum or not.

Action: Answer("B")
Response 1:
Knowledge:

  - The works displayed in the museum are either on loan from private collectors or in the museum's permanent collection.
  - Prints of all of the museum's permanent collection works are available in the museum store.
  - The museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection, such as Hopper's Nighthawks.
  
Action: Answer("B")

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 71 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A person who knowingly brings about misfortune should be blamed for it. However, in some cases a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it. For example, a person should never be blamed for unwittingly bringing about misfortune if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it.
Question: The principles above, if valid, most help to justify the reasoning in which one of the following?
Choices:
  A: Although he would have realized it if he had thought about it, it did not occur to Riley that parking his car in the center lane of Main Street could lead to a traffic accident. So, if a traffic accident does result from Riley's parking his car in the center lane of Main Street, he should not be blamed for it.
  B: Oblicek had no idea that suggesting to her brother that he take out a loan to expand his business was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt, nor could she have reasonably foreseen this. So, if the loan does cause her brother's business to go bankrupt, Oblicek should not be blamed for it.
  C: Gougon had no reason to think that serving the hollandaise sauce would make his guests ill, but he was concerned that it might. Thus, if the hollandaise sauce does make Gougon's guests ill, Gougon should be blamed for it.
  D: When Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine, he did not know that it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. So, if no one else knowingly did anything that contributed to the patient's increase in blood pressure, no one other than Dr. Fitzpatrick is to blame for it.
  E: Any reasonable person could have foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves would start a fire. Thus, even if Kapp did not realize this, she is to blame for starting a fire on Rodriguez's farm since she dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves there.
Response 0:
Knowledge: The passage states that a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it.
A: Riley parked his car in the center lane of Main Street, which could lead to a traffic accident. Although he would have realized it if he had thought about it, it did not occur to him. Therefore, if a traffic accident does result from Riley's parking his car in the center lane of Main Street, he should not be blamed for it.
B: Oblicek had no idea that suggesting to her brother that he take out a loan to expand his business was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt, nor could she have reasonably foreseen this. Therefore, if the loan does cause her brother's business to go bankrupt, Oblicek should not be blamed for it.
C: Gougon had no reason to think that serving the hollandaise sauce would make his guests ill, but he was concerned that it might. Thus, if the hollandaise sauce does make Gougon's guests ill, Gougon should be blamed for it.
D: Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine, which caused the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. However, he did not know that it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. Therefore, if no one else knowingly did anything that contributed to the patient's increase in blood pressure, no one other than Dr. Fitzpatrick is to blame for it.
E: Kapp dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves on Rodriguez's farm, which started a fire. Any reasonable person could have foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves would start a fire. Therefore, even if Kapp did not realize this, she is to blame for starting a fire on Rodriguez's farm since she dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves there.
Action: Answer("B")
Response 1:
Knowledge: The passage states that a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it.
A: Riley parked his car in the center lane of Main Street, which could lead to a traffic accident. Although he would have realized it if he had thought about it, it did not occur to him. Therefore, if a traffic accident does result from Riley's parking his car in the center lane of Main Street, he should not be blamed for it.
B: Oblicek suggested to her brother that he take out a loan to expand his business, but she had no idea that it was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt, nor could she have reasonably foreseen this. Therefore, if the loan does cause her brother's business to go bankrupt, Oblicek should not be blamed for it.
C: Gougon had no reason to think that serving the hollandaise sauce would make his guests ill, but he was concerned that it might. Thus, if the hollandaise sauce does make Gougon's guests ill, Gougon should be blamed for it.
D: Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine, which caused the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. However, he did not know that it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. Therefore, if no one else knowingly did anything that contributed to the patient's increase in blood pressure, no one other than Dr. Fitzpatrick is to blame for it.
E: Kapp dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves on Rodriguez's farm, which started a fire. Any reasonable person could have foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves would start a fire. Therefore, even if Kapp did not realize this, she is to blame for starting a fire on Rodriguez's farm since she dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves there.
Action: Answer("B")

B: Oblicek suggested to her brother that he take out a loan to expand his business, which was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt. She had no idea about it and could not have reasonably foreseen this. This scenario is consistent with the given principles.

He did not know that it would cause the patient to experience increased blood pressure. This scenario is not consistent with the given principles because Dr. Fitzpatrick should have known the possible side effects of the medicine he prescribed.
E: Kapp dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves, which started a fire on Rodriguez's farm. Any reasonable person could have foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves would start a fire. This scenario is not consistent with the given principles because Kapp could have reasonably foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves could start a fire.

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 72 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: People who have specialized knowledge about a scientific or technical issue are systematically excluded from juries for trials where that issue is relevant. Thus, trial by jury is not a fair means of settling disputes involving such issues.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
Choices:
  A: The more complicated the issue being litigated, the less likely it is that a juror without specialized knowledge of the field involved will be able to comprehend the testimony being given.
  B: The more a juror knows about a particular scientific or technical issue involved in a trial, the more likely it is that the juror will be prejudiced in favor of one of the litigating parties before the trial begins.
  C: Appointing an impartial arbitrator is not a fair means of settling disputes involving scientific or technical issues, because arbitrators tend to favor settlements in which both parties compromise on the issues.
  D: Experts who give testimony on scientific or technical issues tend to hedge their conclusions by discussing the possibility of error.
  E: Expert witnesses in specialized fields often command fees that are so high that many people involved in litigation cannot afford their services.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The argument is that people with specialized knowledge are excluded from juries, which makes trial by jury unfair for disputes involving scientific or technical issues.
  A: This choice supports the argument by saying that jurors without specialized knowledge may not be able to comprehend the testimony.
  B: This choice weakens the argument by suggesting that jurors with specialized knowledge may be biased, which undermines the idea that excluding them makes trials fairer.
  C: This choice is irrelevant to the argument because it discusses a different means of settling disputes.
  D: This choice is also irrelevant to the argument because it discusses the behavior of expert witnesses, not jurors.
  E: This choice is also irrelevant to the argument because it discusses the cost of expert witnesses, not the exclusion of jurors.
Action: Answer("B")
Response 1:
Knowledge:
  The argument is that people with specialized knowledge are excluded from juries, which makes trial by jury unfair for disputes involving scientific or technical issues.
  A: This choice supports the argument by saying that jurors without specialized knowledge may not be able to comprehend the testimony.
  B: This choice weakens the argument by saying that jurors with specialized knowledge may be prejudiced in favor of one of the parties.
  C: This choice is irrelevant to the argument because it discusses appointing an arbitrator, not a jury.
  D: This choice is irrelevant to the argument because it discusses how experts give testimony, not how juries are selected.
  E: This choice is irrelevant to the argument because it discusses the cost of expert witnesses, not how juries are selected.

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 73 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Richard: Because it fails to meet the fundamental requirement of art—that it represent—abstract art will eventually be seen as an aberration. Jung-Su: Although artists, like musicians, may reject literal representation, makers of abstract art choose to represent the purely formal features of objects, which are discovered only when everyday perspectives are rejected. Thus, whatever others might come to say, abstract art is part of the artistic mainstream.
Question: Richard and Jung-Su disagree over whether
Choices:
  A: makers of abstract art reject literal representation
  B: the fundamental requirement of art is that it represent
  C: musicians may reject literal representation
  D: abstract art will be seen as an aberration
  E: abstract art is representational
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  Richard argues that abstract art fails to meet the fundamental requirement of art, which is to represent.
  Jung-Su argues that makers of abstract art choose to represent the purely formal features of objects, which are discovered only when everyday perspectives are rejected. Thus, abstract art is part of the artistic mainstream.
  A: Jung-Su agrees that makers of abstract art reject literal representation.
  B: Richard and Jung-Su disagree over whether the fundamental requirement of art is that it represent.
  C: Jung-Su makes a comparison between artists and musicians, but this is not the main point of disagreement between Richard and Jung-Su.
  D: Richard argues that abstract art will eventually be seen as an aberration, but Jung-Su disagrees with this.
  E: Jung-Su argues that abstract art represents the purely formal features of objects.
Action: Answer("B")
Response 1:
Knowledge:

  A: Jung-Su agrees that makers of abstract art reject literal representation.

  C: Jung-Su believes that musicians may reject literal representation.

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 74 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Geologist: The dominant view that petroleum formed from the fossilized remains of plants and animals deep in the earth's crust has been challenged by scientists who hold that it formed, not from living material, but from deep carbon deposits dating from the formation of the earth. But their theory is refuted by the presence in petroleum of biomarkers, molecules indicating the past or present existence of a living organism.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the geologist's argument?
Choices:
  A: Fossils have been discovered that are devoid of biomarkers.
  B: Living organisms only emerged long after the earth's formation.
  C: It would take many millions of years for organisms to become petroleum.
  D: Certain strains of bacteria thrive deep inside the earth's crust.
  E: Some carbon deposits were formed from the fossilized remains of plants.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The geologist argues that the presence of biomarkers in petroleum supports the dominant view that petroleum formed from the fossilized remains of plants and animals.
  A: This weakens the geologist's argument, but it is not directly related to the argument that biomarkers support the dominant view.
  B: This is not relevant to the argument.
  C: This supports the geologist's argument.
  D: This is not relevant to the argument.
  E: This weakens the geologist's argument, as it provides an alternative source for carbon deposits that could form petroleum.
Action: Answer("E")

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 75 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: City leader: If our city adopts the new tourism plan, the amount of money that tourists spend here annually will increase by at least $2 billion, creating as many jobs as a new automobile manufacturing plant would. It would be reasonable for the city to spend the amount of money necessary to convince an automobile manufacturer to build a plant here, but adopting the tourism plan would cost less.
Question: The city leader's statements, if true, provide the most support for which one of the following
Choices:
  A: The city should implement the least expensive job creation measures available.
  B: In general, it is reasonable for the city to spend money to try to convince manufacturing companies to build plants in the city.
  C: The city cannot afford both to spend money to convince an automobile manufacturer to build a plant in the city and to adopt the new tourism plan.
  D: It would be reasonable for the city to adopt the new tourism plan.
  E: The only way the city can create jobs is by increasing tourism.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The city leader believes that adopting the new tourism plan would increase the amount of money that tourists spend in the city annually by at least $2 billion, creating as many jobs as a new automobile manufacturing plant would. The city leader also believes that it would be reasonable for the city to spend the amount of money necessary to convince an automobile manufacturer to build a plant in the city, but adopting the tourism plan would cost less.
  
A: The city leader does not suggest that the city should implement the least expensive job creation measures available. 
B: The city leader suggests that it would be reasonable for the city to spend money to try to convince manufacturing companies to build plants in the city, but only if it is more expensive than adopting the tourism plan.
C: The city leader does not suggest that the city cannot afford both to spend money to convince an automobile manufacturer to build a plant in the city and to adopt the new tourism plan.
D: The city leader suggests that it would be reasonable for the city to adopt the new tourism plan.
E: The city leader does not suggest that the only way the city can create jobs is by increasing tourism.

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 76 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Student: If a person has an immunity to infection by a microorganism, then that microorganism does not cause them to develop harmful symptoms. Since many people are exposed to staphylococcus without developing any harmful symptoms, it follows that they have an immunity to infection by this microorganism.
Question: The student's argument is most similar in its flawed pattern of reasoning to which one of the following?
Choices:
  A: Everything morally right is just, but some actions that best serve the interests of everyone are not just. Thus, some morally right actions do not serve the interests of everyone.
  B: Advertisers try to persuade people that certain claims are true. Since writers of fiction are not advertisers, they probably never try to persuade people that certain claims are true.
  C: Isabel said that she would take the medication. Obviously, though, she did not do so, because medication either cures disease or alleviates its symptoms, and Isabel is still quite ill.
  D: When business owners are subjected to excessive taxation, they become less willing to expand their businesses. The recent decline in business expansions thus shows that their taxes are too high.
  E: Studies show that doctors tend to wash their hands less often than any other health care professionals. This shows that the procedure cannot be of much value in preventing disease.
Response 0:
Knowledge: The student's argument is based on the assumption that exposure to staphylococcus without developing any harmful symptoms implies that the person has an immunity to infection by this microorganism. This assumption is not necessarily true, as some people may be carriers of the microorganism without developing symptoms, and others may have developed immunity through vaccination or previous exposure.
A: This argument is flawed because it assumes that everything morally right is just, which is not necessarily true.
B: This argument is flawed because it assumes that writers of fiction never try to persuade people that certain claims are true, which is not necessarily true.
C: This argument is flawed because it assumes that medication always cures disease or alleviates its symptoms, which is not necessarily true.
D: This argument is flawed because it assumes that the recent decline in business expansions is solely due to excessive taxation, which is not necessarily true.
E: This argument is flawed because it assumes that doctors' hand-washing practices are the only factor affecting the value of the procedure in preventing disease.
Action: Answer("C")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  The student's argument is based on the assumption that exposure to staphylococcus without developing any harmful symptoms implies immunity to infection by this microorganism, which is not necessarily true.
  A: This argument is flawed because it confuses moral rightness with serving the interests of everyone.
  B: This argument is flawed because it assumes that writers of fiction never try to persuade people that certain claims are true, which is not necessarily true.
  C: This argument is flawed because it assumes that medication always cures disease or alleviates its symptoms, which is not necessarily true.
  D: This argument is flawed because it assumes that the recent decline in business expansions is solely due to excessive taxation, which is not necessarily true.
  E: This argument is flawed because it assumes that doctors' behavior is representative of the effectiveness of handwashing in preventing disease, which is not necessarily true.

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 77 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Journalist: A book claiming that a new drug has dangerous side effects has recently been criticized by a prominent physician. However, the physician is employed by the company that manufactures that drug, and hence probably has personal reasons to deny that the drug is dangerous. Therefore, the critique does not provide legitimate grounds to reject the book's claims about the drug's side effects.
Question: The reasoning in the journalist's argument is most vulnerable to criticism on which one of the following grounds?
Choices:
  A: It fails to address adequately the possibility that the critique of the book called into question other claims made in the book in addition to the claim that the drug has dangerous side effects.
  B: It takes for granted that anyone even remotely associated with a company that manufactures a drug is unable to fairly weigh evidence concerning possible dangerous side effects of that drug.
  C: It overlooks the possibility that the author of the book was biased for personal reasons in favor of the claim that the drug has dangerous side effects.
  D: It fails to address adequately the possibility that someone who has personal reasons to deny a claim may nonetheless provide legitimate grounds for denying that claim.
  E: It overlooks the possibility that even if a critique does not provide legitimate grounds to reject a claim, this failure need not be the result of any personal biases of the author.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The journalist argues that the critique of the book claiming that a new drug has dangerous side effects does not provide legitimate grounds to reject the book's claims about the drug's side effects because the physician who criticized the book is employed by the company that manufactures the drug and hence probably has personal reasons to deny that the drug is dangerous.

B: This choice is a criticism of the journalist's argument because it suggests that the journalist takes for granted that the physician is unable to fairly weigh evidence concerning possible dangerous side effects of the drug.

D: This choice is a possible criticism of the journalist's argument, but it does not directly address the vulnerability of the journalist's reasoning.
E: This choice is not a criticism of the journalist's argument, but rather a general statement that does not address the vulnerability of the journalist's reasoning.
Action: Answer("B")

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 78 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: University president: Research institutions have an obligation to promote research in any field of theoretical investigation if that research shows some promise of yielding insights into the causes of practical problems that affect people's quality of life.
Question: The principle stated by the university president, ifvalid, most helps to justitY which one of the following actions?
Choices:
  A: A university denies a grant application from a fucuity member for work on a solurion to a tiunous mathematical puzzle that has no relation to practical concerns.
  B: A government agency funds a research project in astrophysics designed to determine whether there are theoretical limits on the magnitude of planets in distant solar systems.
  C: A university funds a research position in the pbysics department that involves no teaching but has the responsibility for managing all the grant applications by members of the physics fucuity.
  D: A foundation decides not to fund a research proposal in applied mathematics that sought to model certain poorly understood aspects of economic behavior.
  E: A research institute funds an investigation into the mathematical properties offolded structures that is likely to aid in understanding the structure of proteins that cause disease.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The university president believes that research institutions have an obligation to promote research in any field of theoretical investigation if that research shows some promise of yielding insights into the causes of practical problems that affect people's quality of life.
  A: The research has no relation to practical concerns.
  B: The research is in astrophysics and does not relate to practical problems that affect people's quality of life.
  C: The research position involves managing grant applications and does not relate to the promotion of research in any field of theoretical investigation that shows promise of yielding insights into the causes of practical problems that affect people's quality of life.
  D: The research proposal sought to model certain poorly understood aspects of economic behavior, but it is not clear whether it relates to practical problems that affect people's quality of life.
  E: The research is likely to aid in understanding the structure of proteins that cause disease, which is a practical problem that affects people's quality of life.
Action: Answer("E")

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 79 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A high-calorie diet providing adequate fats was a crucial requirement for the evolution of the anatomically modem human brain, a process that began among our early human ancestors. Food resources that could support such a diet were most abundant and reliable in the shore environments that were available to early humans. Nevertheless, the human brain's evolution took place almost exclusively in savanna and woodland areas.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, would most help to resolve the apparent conflict presented above?
Choices:
  A: Early humans had a significantly lower metabolic rate than anatomically modem humans,allowing them to expend their fat reserves more efficiently.
  B: The brains of the earliest known humans were 30 percent smaller than the anatomically modem human brain.
  C: Prehistoric savanna and woodland areas offered more reliable and abundant resources than they do today.
  D: The techniques used to explore the archaeology of prehistoric shore sites have only recently been developed.
  E: Gathering food in shore enviromnents required a significantly greater expenditure of calories by early humans than did gathering food in other environments.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The passage states that a high-calorie diet providing adequate fats was a crucial requirement for the evolution of the anatomically modern human brain, and that food resources that could support such a diet were most abundant and reliable in the shore environments that were available to early humans. However, the human brain's evolution took place almost exclusively in savanna and woodland areas.
  
A: This statement is not relevant to the apparent conflict presented in the passage.
B: This statement is not relevant to the apparent conflict presented in the passage.
C: This statement does not resolve the apparent conflict presented in the passage.
D: This statement is not relevant to the apparent conflict presented in the passage.
E: If gathering food in shore environments required a significantly greater expenditure of calories by early humans than did gathering food in other environments, then this could help to explain why the human brain's evolution took place almost exclusively in savanna and woodland areas, despite the fact that food resources that could support a high-calorie diet were most abundant and reliable in the shore environments that were available to early humans.
Action: Answer("E")

E: This statement suggests that gathering food in shore environments required a significantly greater expenditure of calories by early humans than did gathering food in other environments. This could help to explain why the human brain's evolution took place almost exclusively in savanna and woodland areas, despite the fact that food resources that could support a high-calorie diet providing adequate fats were most abundant and reliable in the shore environments that were available to early humans.
Action: Answer("E")
Response 9:
Knowledge: 
  The passage states that a high-calorie diet providing adequate fats was a crucial requirement for the evolution of the anatomically modern human brain, and that food resources that could support such a diet were most abundant and reliable in the shore environments that were available to early humans. However, the human brain's evolution took place almost exclusively in savanna and woodland areas.
  
A: This statement is about the metabolic rate of early humans, but it does not help to resolve the apparent conflict presented in the passage.
B: This statement provides information about the size of the earliest known human brains, but it does not help to resolve the apparent conflict presented in the passage.
C: This statement contradicts the information presented in the passage, which states that the human brain's evolution took place almost exclusively in savanna and woodland areas.
D: This statement provides information about the techniques used to explore the archaeology of prehistoric shore sites, but it does not help to resolve the apparent conflict presented in the passage.
E: This statement provides a possible explanation for why early humans did not evolve their brains in shore environments, as it suggests that gathering food in shore environments required a significantly greater expenditure of calories by early humans than did gathering food in other environments.

Action: Answer("E")
Votes: E, E, E, E, E, C, E, E, E, E

### Exam: lsat-lr-100 | Temperature: 1.0 | Problem 80 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Sarah: When commercial fishing boats with permits to fish for certain species accidentally catch a type of fish for which they have no permit, the latter must be thrown back. This is a very wasteful practice because many, if not most, of the rejected fish do not survive. Fishing permits should therefore be altered so that fishers can keep fish caught accidentally. Amar: Making it legal to keep those fish would probably lead to a lot more "accidents."
Question: The technique Amar uses in responding to Sarah's argument is to
Choices:
  A: question whether Sarah's recommendation can be put into practice
  B: point out that Sarah used a crucial term in two distinct senses
  C: allude to a factor that supposedly strengthens the case for Sarah's recommendation
  D: contend that Sarah's recommendation has an important negative consequence
  E: maintain that Sarah overlooks important lessons from past policies
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  Amar is responding to Sarah's argument that fishing permits should be altered so that fishers can keep fish caught accidentally. Amar argues that making it legal to keep those fish would probably lead to a lot more "accidents."
  A: Amar is not questioning whether Sarah's recommendation can be put into practice.
  B: Amar is not pointing out that Sarah used a crucial term in two distinct senses.
  C: Amar is not alluding to a factor that supposedly strengthens the case for Sarah's recommendation.
  D: Amar is contending that Sarah's recommendation has an important negative consequence.
  E: Amar is not maintaining that Sarah overlooks important lessons from past policies.
Action: Answer("D")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  Amar is responding to Sarah's argument that fishing permits should be altered so that fishers can keep fish caught accidentally, which is a recommendation to solve the problem of wasteful practice of throwing back the fish that are caught accidentally.
  Amar's response is that making it legal to keep those fish would probably lead to a lot more "accidents."

Topic: Law
Context: Principle: Employees of telemarketing agencies should never do anything that predisposes people to dislike the agencies' clients. Application: If an employee of a telemarketing agency has been told by a person the employee has called that he or she does not want to buy the product of a client of the agency, the employee should
Question: Which one of the following, if true, justifies the given application of the principle above?
Choices:
  A: Any employee of a telemarketing agency is likely to be able to detennine whether trying to talk someone into buying the product of a client of the agency after the person has said that he or she does not want to will likely engender nimosity toward the client.
  B: Some employees oftelemarketing agencies are unlikely to be certain about whether trying to talk someone into buying the product of a client of the agency after the person has said that he or she does not want to will likely engenderanimosity toward the client.
  C: Any employee of a telemarketing agency who tries to get someone to buy the product of a client of the agency after the person has said that he or she does not want to will engender animosity toward the client.
  D: Some people that an employee of a telemarketing agency calls to ask them to buy the product of a client of the agency will refuse to do so even though they are not predisposed to dislike the client.
  E: People who are already predisposed to dislike the client of a te1emarketiug agency are more likely to refuse to buy the product of that client than are people who are predisposed to like the client.
Response 0:
Knowledge: The principle states that employees of telemarketing agencies should never do anything that predisposes people to dislike the agencies' clients. We need to find the option that justifies this application of the principle.

E: This option talks about people who are already predisposed to dislike the client of a telemarketing agency. This option is not relevant to the given application of the principle.
